title: Love is a Battlefield (And Everyone's Losing)
plot_outline: Buzz's carefully constructed solitude is disrupted when they're forced to interact with their parole officer. As secret revealed at worst time, both characters must confront their issues with trust, intimacy, and the fact that rock bottom isn't the bottom.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Buzz begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of running out of their vice of choice. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Buzz into the situation.

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: I don't do charity work, and I don't do favors.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

dialogue.speaker: Buzz
dialogue.line: Things just keep getting worse.
dialogue.tone: slurred optimism fighting against bitter reality
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: Next time, count me out.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: terrified of being vulnerable again

visual_details.setting_description: A place where life happens to people who've stopped trying to control it

character_appearances.Karen the Social Worker: Tired, worn down, but still clinging to whatever dignity remains
character_appearances.Dumbo: droopy, bloodshot, crusty pizza slice, stained remote control, empty beer cans, showing signs of emotional damage

scenes.title: When Bad Gets Worse
scenes.action: The situation escalates when law enforcement becomes involved. What seemed like a manageable problem reveals itself to be connected to larger issues involving their own psychological damage. Buzz realizes they're in deeper than anticipated and that their usual strategy of "ignore it and hope it goes away" won't work this time.

scenes.title: Same Shit, Different Day
scenes.action: The episode concludes with Buzz having learned nothing from their experience but somehow finding themselves in a slightly different variation of the same situation they started in. Victory is redefined as "not making things significantly worse," and the audience is reminded that some problems don't get solvedâ€”they just get replaced with new problems.

dialogue.speaker: Karen the Social Worker
dialogue.line: Why do I always get involved in these situations?
dialogue.tone: weary sarcasm
dialogue.subtext: revealing more about their pain than intended

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: I've seen this shit before, it doesn't end well.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: testing whether this person can be trusted

dialogue.speaker: Karen the Social Worker
dialogue.line: Some lessons are learned the hard way.
dialogue.tone: weary sarcasm
dialogue.subtext: desperately wants to be proven wrong about people
